themes: Overemphasis on tourism in funding priorities
Problems with funding calendar and fiscal year alignment
Disconnect between arts community and broader community/businesses
Lack of discipline-specific and knowledgeable review panels
Inclusion of commercial businesses in nonprofit funding pools
Administrative confusion and inefficiency (third party administrator, information access)
key_phrases: The focus on tourists is detrimental to the community and has weakened our ecosystem
calendar change that's supposed to be happening this year is also highly detrimental
we have to know what our funding situation will be
connect the arts community to the wider community and to encourage businesses/developers to do more to support us
recent focus on equity and accessibility was much-needed, it has been disastrous in practice
very little accountability in the present system
Return to discipline-specific and budget-level panels with more local representation
Commercial businesses should not be included in local arts funding
Do away with the third party administrator
We spend our time being sent from the Long Center to the City and back again
barriers_identified: Overemphasis on tourism over community needs
Misaligned funding calendar with organizational programming
Lack of connection between arts and broader community/businesses
Equity and accessibility measures resulting in unintended exclusion
Panels lacking expertise and local representation
Competition from commercial businesses for nonprofit funds
solutions_proposed: Use the full text of the HOT statute in creating guidelines
Allow resources to strengthen and grow a vibrant arts ecosystem
Align funding calendar with organizational programming (suggest July - August year)
Connect arts community to wider community and encourage business/developer support
Return to discipline-specific and budget-level panels with knowledgeable local representation
Exclude commercial businesses from competing with nonprofits for local arts funding
Eliminate the third party administrator and centralize information access
